title: Dreaming of games like Southampton's League Cup semi against Liverpool kept Jay Rodriguez going during 15-month injury hell
text:
Share this video Watch Next 
"So for me the game is definitely important to us and we will definitely be fired up for it because it is something we won't want to have taken away from us.” 
Rodriguez had gone into the contest that ended his season - away to Manchester City - level on 15 league goals with Sergio Aguero and Wayne Rooney. 
He’d made his England debut against Chile the previous November and worked hard to put himself in with a shout of being named in Roy Hodgson's World Cup squad. 
Although he has only four goals to his name this season, he hasn’t given up on forcing his way into new Three Lions boss Gareth Southgate’s plans. 
“That’s the best place to be as player,” he added. Ambitious Rodriguez has unfinished business with international football (Photo: Rex) 
“It’s the one thing you want to do. To have a little taste of it I learnt so much in a few weeks. You just want more and more of it. 
“You improve as a player and a person. I learnt a lot because I was playing with great players. 
“I remember thinking, 'I’m training against Lampard, Gerrard and Rooney, this is a massive standard.' The way they worked was world class. It was an unbelievable feeling.” 
It is the reason why he understands the decision of players such as Lallana to move on. 
“You look at where they have gone and they have done really well,” said Rodriguez. Former team-mates Lallana and Rodriguez are opponents in this EFL Cup semi (Photo: Getty) 
“It’s nice to play with those sorts of players. It can’t get any better. It was an amazing experience for myself with England.” 
Claude Puel's Saints go into Wednesday's semi-final first leg as underdogs despite playing at home, having lost three of their last four games and drawn the other. 
They will also be without Jose Fonte, one of their best two defenders and the club captain, as his transfer wrangle continues. Liverpool won't have to worry about wantaway Saints skipper Fonte (Photo: Getty) 
Liverpool, meanwhile, have lost only twice all season and have a hungry group of players who will be well rested after Jurgen Klopp chose to field a young side in the FA Cup against Plymouth on Sunday. 
But Rodriguez revealed an unlikely source has contributed to the belief he has going into matches just like this one - former Saints boss Mauricio Pochettino. 
The Spurs chief sent his ex-player a supportive text after his two goals against Bournemouth last month. 
Rodriguez said: “He just said that he was really happy for me that I’d scored and that he was happy to see me out in the field. News of Rodriguez returning to form delighted his former boss Pochettino (Photo: Getty) 
“He called me after the game. It was really nice to speak with him and reminisce. 
“He just wanted to improve you as a player and a person. He always spoke to you and helped out. He was always seeing things in your game that you were weak at, but he also gave you that belief that you are a good player.”
